title: https://mastodon.ngo

last_post.content:
#introduction

A few weeks ago there was a discussion about the need for a #Mastodon instance dedicated to NGOs, nonprofits, and folks in the human rights space.

So I got to work with @happy and @gillo and created https://mastodon.ngo! We're admin'ing this instance together and we'll be maintaining it for the long term.

If you or your organization or someone you know is interested in creating an account, let me know. You can also request an account here: https://mastodon.ngo/about

title: Here’s how The Washington Post verified its journalists on Mastodon

last_post.content:
@tchambers You’re onto something there. Of course legacy blue checks are gone now ( or just hidden in code ), but even for just “how do I get verified”, a hand holding walk through would be helpful.

There’s quirks to how it works. Even Washington Post had an issue where the verification didn’t work because the page size was too large. How would a normal person ever figure out that issue. https://washpost.engineering/heres-how-the-washington-post-verified-its-journalists-on-mastodon-7b5dbc96985c

title: Announcements

last_post.content:
In the UK tomorrow at 3pm there is going to be a system wide test run on our emergency alert system.

If you have a mobile phone that you DON'T want others to know about (people looking to leave partners, kids with controlling parents, anyone for any reason) then make sure you TURN IT OFF. Otherwise it is highly likely to be making a loud alarm sound for the duration of the test, even if it's on silent.

Be safe ♥

Edit: https://www.gov.uk/alerts/announcements

title: Researchers Blasted Google And "60 Minutes" Over AI Claims

last_post.content:
"Artificial intelligence researchers are calling out both CBS and Google for overhyping AI after the network aired a high-profile 60 Minutes interview with Google CEO Sundar Pichai on Sunday. In the segment, correspondent Scott Pelley claimed that an AI program made by Google had learned a language it had never seen before all by itself, and Pichai referred to AI tech as a “black box” that even the people who worked in the field didn’t fully understand."
https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/pranavdixit/google-60-minutes-ai-claims-challenged

title: Study Results: How well do harassment prevention interventions transfer between communities?

last_post.content:
In oral arguments, Supreme Court justices asked a question that we can answer with science: do policies against harassment cause a chilling effect on freedom of expression?

In multiple large-scale field experiments, we have found that policies that restrict harmful speech actually increase the free exercise of speech rights.

Here's our latest data: https://citizensandtech.org/2022/08/harassment-prevention-across-communities/

title: What It’s Like To Stop Using Google Search - Debugger

last_post.content:
"What It's Like To Stop Using Google Search"

Most of the time I don't notice a thing ...

... because a surprisingly large fraction of my searches are navigational ("where's the site for that *thing* again?") or informational at a level that's trivially easy for any search service at all

So the actual cost of switching is ... pretty low

(DuckDuckGo's my main search these days)

My essay on it: https://debugger.medium.com/what-its-like-to-stop-using-google-search-fbdf9919c551

"Friend" link if you're not a Medium subscriber: https://debugger.medium.com/what-its-like-to-stop-using-google-search-fbdf9919c551?sk=723a09d252b9f8558f08e1551b2b6896

title: Solar Protocol

last_post.content:
I have a new game! And it is out now:

Drift Mine Satellite is a maintenance text adventure about a person living underground in a limestone mine, and their work on the local communication network that has sprung up there.

It is a utopian apocalypse fantasy, a forever-camping world narrowed to linear miles of RVs parked under a mountain, the people who live in them, and the systems that interconnect them, both social and material.

Find Drift Mine Satellite here; http://solarprotocol.net/sunthinking/#pipkin

🛰️

title: Why Silicon Valley is bringing eugenics back

last_post.content:
Silicon Valley’s elite made their billions through luck, not genius. But as the public turns on them, they want to protect their privilege, so they’re trying to convince us they’re inherently superior.

For Disconnect, I explain how billionaires like Elon Musk are bringing eugenics back by promoting effective altruism, longtermism, and pronatalism. The goal is to cement their position at the top, and we need to stop them.

https://www.disconnect.blog/p/why-silicon-valley-is-bringing-eugenics

#tech #elonmusk #inequality

title: Towards a Bibliography for AI Systems | Ryan C. Cordell

last_post.content:
For those interested, I’ve posted the text of my talk "Toward a Bibliography for AI Systems" on my website: https://ryancordell.org/research/aibibliography/

I titled the talk "*Toward* a Bibliography" because this is very preliminary research, but I do expect to keep working in this direction. I think I best express the deep impetus for the work toward the end of the talk: "Bringing together bibliographical and computational approaches allows us to perceive AI systems not as unknowable oracles but instead bound, describable, and comparable cultural artifacts. "

I am presenting this talk even *as I post this* as part of the Society of Fellows in Critical Bibliography’s symposium today on "Preserving and Analyzing Digital Texts" https://rarebookschool.org/all-programs/events/preserving-and-analyzing-digital-texts/

title: Konrad Kording (@kordinglab@neuromatch.social)

last_post.content: The reason your ML professor keeps prattling on about data leakage and insisting you set aside a test set and use it *only* for validation, making sure that at validation time the data on which you predict is entirely novel for the model, is not merely that she's a stuck-up, inflexible bore. It's also because publishing and subsequently debunking papers that don't do that is a colossal waste of resources. Thank you for your work, @kordinglab https://neuromatch.social/@kordinglab/110155049278014769

title: The End of Roe Will Bring About a Sea Change in the Encryption Debate

last_post.content:
The #EARNITAct is about to be introduced in the Senate... for the third time.

I've heard the text will be the same as last time (spring 2022).

Know what's different from last time? We no longer have Roe v. Wade.

I've said it before and I'll say it again: You cannot be both pro-choice and anti-encryption.

The Dem Senators who introduce & support EARN IT will be showing you their true stance.

https://cyberlaw.stanford.edu/blog/2022/05/end-roe-will-bring-about-sea-change-encryption-debate

title: youtube.com/watch?v=-TBrV4-Lpn...

last_post.content: Come see me and my large video at the Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum on Saturday afternoon (if you are in Columbus, Ohio)! I'm so proud and excited to have been part of this exhibition that opened in November 2022 and closes in a few weeks about Bill Blackbeard 75-ton (yes, 150,000 pounds) collection of newspaper comics—if it weren’t for him, we’d have a very thin record of American cartooning history. https://cartoons.osu.edu/events/newspaper-comics-printing-and-papercraft-day/ (You can watch my video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-TBrV4-LpnA )

title: What Follows from Empirical Software Research?

last_post.content:
When asking questions about how we should program many people say “follow the research”. But how does that work exactly? Let’s idealize for a moment. What if we had a perfect study with deep relevance to practitioners. What should we do with it?

The answer is far from the simplistic version people often give. So I wrote a post exploring it in depth.

https://jimmyhmiller.github.io/empirical

title: google.com/search?q=climate+ch...

last_post.content:
Search for "climate change" in #Google and you'll get a Google-generated list of buttons to help focus your search: Overview, Effects, Causes, Videos, Actions, and Authors. Great idea, esp. the Actions button.
https://www.google.com/search?q=climate+change&bshm=foot/1

Does G do this only for climate change? I can't find similar buttons when I search for other important causes like voter registration, reproductive rights, or homelessness.

#Climate #ClimateChange
cc. @searchliaison

title:
~akkartik/snap.love -

graph drawing tool -

sourcehut git

last_post.content:
A little app for drawing graphs

https://git.sr.ht/~akkartik/snap.love

I've wanted something like this for a long time. Intended for small graphs where laying things out by hand is not too painful, and it's nice that things don't move around every time I make a change, as happens with graphviz (https://graphviz.org). The file format is also amenable to git; no long lines, and adding new nodes or edges doesn't reorder unrelated nodes and edges.
